skill.name: schema-research
skill.description: Schema.org research assistant for Logseq Template Graph. Investigates Schema.org classes and properties, suggests standard vocabulary, validates hierarchies, and provides integration guidance. Use when adding new classes/properties, researching Schema.org standards, or planning template expansions.
skill.summary: Schema.org research assistant for Logseq Template Graph. Investigates Schema.org classes and propert...
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation and research skill with no executable code. It provides guidance on researching Schema.org vocabulary for Logseq template development. The helper scripts only open URLs in browsers. No security risks detected.

content.value_statement: Building Logseq templates requires understanding Schema.org standards. This skill researches classes, properties, and hierarchies to ensure proper integration.
actual_capabilities: Fetches Schema.org class definitions and properties
Maps Schema.org types to Logseq property types
Suggests module placement for new classes
limitations: Requires manual WebFetch calls to schema.org

use_cases.title: Research new Schema.org classes
use_cases.description: Investigate Recipe, MedicalCondition, or any Schema.org class before adding to templates

use_cases.title: Find missing properties for existing classes
use_cases.description: Discover what Schema.org properties are missing from Person, Organization, or Event classes

use_cases.title: Validate type mappings and hierarchies
use_cases.description: Ensure proper Logseq type mapping and inheritance for Schema.org vocabulary

prompt_templates.title: Research new class
prompt_templates.prompt: Research the Recipe class from Schema.org. Show its hierarchy, properties, and recommend how to integrate it into our Logseq template.

prompt_templates.title: Find missing properties
prompt_templates.prompt: What Schema.org properties are missing from our Person class? Compare with the official Schema.org definition and prioritize the most important ones.

prompt_templates.title: Validate type mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Should 'birthDate' be :date or :default type in Logseq? Check Schema.org and explain the best mapping.

prompt_templates.title: Module placement
prompt_templates.prompt: Where should I add the MedicalCondition class? Analyze the hierarchy and recommend the best module placement.

output_examples.input: Research the Recipe class from Schema.org
output: Definition: A recipe with cooking instructions and ingredients
Required properties: recipeIngredient, cookTime, prepTime, recipeInstructions

best_practices: Always fetch the latest Schema.org definition before adding classes
Check existing template structure to avoid duplicates
Map Schema.org types correctly to Logseq types (:default, :node, :date, :url, :number)
anti_patterns: Don't add classes without researching Schema.org hierarchy first
Don't create properties without checking if they already exist
Don't ignore cardinality guidelines from Schema.org examples

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with all Logseq versions?
faq.answer: Yes, it provides research guidance that works with any Logseq DB version supporting templates.

faq.question: What are the limitations of Schema.org research?
faq.answer: The skill researches vocabulary but cannot automatically create or modify template files.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my existing templates?
faq.answer: Yes, use the research output to manually add classes and properties to your templates.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill only researches public Schema.org vocabulary and doesn't access your private data.

faq.question: What if Schema.org vocabulary changes?
faq.answer: The skill fetches live data from Schema.org, ensuring you get the most current definitions.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual Schema.org research?
faq.answer: It automates the research process and provides Logseq-specific integration guidance.
